unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: P-value of a 1-sided Test When Given the z-score
question_text:
A significance test was used to test the null hypothesis ${ H }_{ 0 }$: $p =0.34$ versus the alternative ${ H }_{ a }$: $p <0.34$. The resulting test statistic is $z=-0.83$.
The $P$-value for this test is approximately:
solution:
Since the alternative includes $<$ we want to find the probability that $z < -0.83$.

Below is a picture of the data:

Created for Albert.io. Copyright 2017. All rights reserved.

Method 1: Solving by Using the Standard Normal Distribution Chart

Looking at the z-score table find the probability that $z<-0.83$. This gives a probability of $0.2033$.

Method 2: Using the TI Graphing Calculator

Using the normalcdf function(located by hitting 2nd Vars).
$normalcdf(-99999,-0.83,0,1)=0.2033$

Below is the calculator input on the TI-84. Since we are dealing with z-scores the mean is $0$ and standard deviation is $1$. We want our lower value to be a very small number so that is why it is $-99999$.

Explanation of Distractors Choice 'B' is incorrect as that is the probability of $z<-0.38$. Choice 'C' is incorrect as that is the probability of $z\neq -0.83$. Choice 'D' is incorrect as that is the probability of $z\neq -0.38$. Choice 'E' is incorrect as that is the probability of $z>-0.83$.
